question:
Which of the following is NOT a condition for the President’s office in India?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)
option_1: He shall not be entitled, without payment of rent, to use his official residence
option_2: He shall not be a member of either House of the Parliament.
option_3: The allowances shall not be diminished during his term of office.
option_4: He shall not hold any office of profit.
solution:
As per Article 59 of the Indian Constitution, which deals with the conditions of the President’s office, the following are true:

(b) He shall not be a member of either House of the Parliament – Correct

The President must resign from Parliament or any legislature before assuming office.

(c) The allowances shall not be diminished during his term of office – Correct

This ensures financial independence during the President’s tenure.

(d) He shall not hold any office of profit – Correct

This prevents conflict of interest and ensures impartiality.

(a) He shall not be entitled, without payment of rent, to use his official residence – Incorrect

In fact, the President is entitled to use the official residence (Rashtrapati Bhavan) without paying rent.

Conclusion:

Option (a) contradicts the actual provision, hence it's NOT a valid condition.

question:
Which Article of the Constitution of India expressly provides that the President is eligible for re-election?

SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
Article 57 of the Indian Constitution expressly provides that a person who holds or has held the office of President shall be eligible for re-election to that office.

This means the President of India can contest for the office more than once.

There is no limit on the number of terms a person can serve as President, as long as they fulfill the eligibility criteria.

Important Articles to remember:

Article 52 – There shall be a President of India.

Article 56 – Term of office of President (5 years).

Article 57 – Re-election eligibility.

Article 58 – Qualifications for election as President.

question:
In the state legislative assembly, the Money bill can be introduced with the prior permission of __________.

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
In a State Legislative Assembly, a Money Bill can only be introduced with the prior recommendation of the Governor.

This is mentioned under Article 207 of the Indian Constitution, which corresponds to Article 110 for Parliament.

Just like at the Centre, where the President’s recommendation is needed, in states the Governor's recommendation is mandatory for introducing a Money Bill.

Only a Minister can introduce a Money Bill, not a private member.

Key Point:

A Money Bill relates to matters like taxation, borrowing of money, expenditure from the Consolidated Fund, etc.

question:
As per article 123, the ordinance making power is the most important legislative power of ____________.

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_4: Chief Justice of India
solution:
Article 123 of the Indian Constitution gives the President the power to promulgate ordinances when Parliament is not in session.

This is considered the most important legislative power of the President.

Ordinances have the same force and effect as laws passed by Parliament.

However, they must be approved by Parliament within 6 weeks of reassembling, or they cease to operate.

Key facts:

Ordinance can be issued only on the advice of the Council of Ministers.

It is a temporary law-making power used in urgent situations.

question:
Which Article of the Constitution of India provides that ‘there shall be a Vice President of India’?

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
Article 63 of the Constitution of India states:

“There shall be a Vice-President of India.”

It establishes the post of the Vice President as a constitutional office.

The Vice President is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (Council of States).

The term of office of the Vice President is 5 years (as per Article 67).

In case of a vacancy in the office of the President, the Vice President acts as President until a new one is elected (Article 65).

Other Relevant Articles:

Article 61 – Procedure for impeachment of the President

Article 62 – Time of holding election to fill a vacancy in the office of President

Article 65 – Vice President to act as President in case of vacancy

question:
How many members are nominated by the President to the Rajya Sabha?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
The President of India nominates 12 members to the Rajya Sabha (Council of States).

This is provided under Article 80(1)(a) of the Constitution.

These members are nominated for their special knowledge or practical experience in the fields of:

Literature

Science

Art

Social Service

The objective is to enrich parliamentary debates with expert input from various fields.

Total strength of Rajya Sabha: 250

238 elected by states and Union Territories

12 nominated by the President

question:
The ________ of every state unfurls the flag in its capital on the Republic Day.

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)
option_1: Judge of High Court
solution:
On Republic Day (26th January), the Governor of each state unfurls the national flag at the state capital.

This is a ceremonial responsibility of the Governor, who is the constitutional head of the state.

At the national level, the President of India unfurls the flag at Rajpath (now Kartavya Path), New Delhi.

Important Distinction:

Independence Day (15th August):

The Chief Minister hoists the flag in the state capital.

Republic Day (26th January):

The Governor unfurls the flag in the state capital.

question:
Which of the following Articles states that the Prime Minister should be appointed by the President?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
Article 75(1) of the Constitution of India clearly states:

"The Prime Minister shall be appointed by the President."

The President appoints the Prime Minister, but in practice, the person who commands the majority in the Lok Sabha is chosen.

The Council of Ministers is also appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister.

The Prime Minister is the head of the government, while the President is the ceremonial head of state.

Other Articles:

Article 66 – Election of the Vice President

Article 62 – Time for election to fill a vacancy in the office of President

Article 71 – Matters relating to election of President and Vice President

question:
Which of the following is the most controversial Article in the Indian Constitution, which provides President’s rule in any state?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
Article 356 of the Indian Constitution allows the President to impose President’s Rule in a state if the constitutional machinery fails.

This means if the state government is unable to function according to the provisions of the Constitution, the President can assume control over the state.

It is considered the most controversial Article because it has been misused multiple times in Indian political history to dismiss elected state governments.

The S.R. Bommai case (1994) laid down strict guidelines to curb misuse of Article 356.

Other Articles:

Article 352 – National Emergency

Article 358 – Suspension of Fundamental Rights during National Emergency

Article 360 – Financial Emergency

question:
Who is considered the highest law officer of the state in India?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)
option_3: Chief justice of high court
solution:
The Advocate General is considered the highest law officer of a state in India.

This post is created under Article 165 of the Indian Constitution.

The Advocate General is appointed by the Governor of the state and must be qualified to be a judge of a High Court.

Their role is to advise the state government on legal matters and represent the state in legal proceedings.

Key Differences:

Advocate General – Highest law officer at the state level

Attorney General – Highest law officer at the national level

question:
Which Article deals with the election of the President?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
Article 54 of the Indian Constitution deals with the election of the President of India.

It states that the President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college, consisting of:

The elected members of both Houses of Parliament, and

The elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States and Union territories (Delhi & Puducherry).

Important Articles:

Article 54 – Election of the President

Article 66 – Election of the Vice President

Article 72 – Pardoning powers of the President

Article 74 – Council of Ministers to aid and advise the President

question:
As per article 158, the Governor shall NOT be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State specified in ___________ Schedule.

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
According to Article 158(2) of the Indian Constitution:

"The Governor shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State specified in the First Schedule."

The First Schedule of the Constitution lists all the States and Union Territories of India.

This provision ensures the neutrality and impartiality of the Governor, who is a constitutional head, not a political functionary.

Key Point:

A Governor must resign from any legislative position before assuming office.

question:
Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with the election of the Vice President?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
The election of the Vice President of India is dealt with under Part V of the Indian Constitution.

Specifically, it is covered in Article 66.

Part V of the Constitution is titled “The Union” and it includes provisions related to:

The President

The Vice President

Council of Ministers

Attorney General

Parliament

Key Facts:

The Vice President is elected by an electoral college consisting of members of both Houses of Parliament (elected + nominated).

He is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha.

question:
Who among the following was the shortest-serving Prime Minister of India?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
 Gulzarilal Nanda holds the record for being the shortest-serving Prime Minister of India.

 He served twice as acting Prime Minister, each time for only 13 days:

After the death of Jawaharlal Nehru in 1964

2. After the death of Lal Bahadur Shastri in 1966

 Although Atal Bihari Vajpayee also served a short 13-day term in 1996, he was a full Prime Minister, not acting. Gulzarilal Nanda’s tenure was even shorter in functional authority as a caretaker PM.

List of Short Terms:

 Gulzarilal Nanda – 13 days (acting PM, twice)

 Atal Bihari Vajpayee – 13 days (full PM in 1996)

 Charan Singh – ~170 days

 Chandra Shekhar – ~223 days

question:
In case the President is satisfied with the Governor’s report, he may declare President’s Rule under Article 356 but such proclamation is initially for a period of ________.

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
Under Article 356 of the Indian Constitution, if the President is satisfied (usually based on the Governor's report) that the state government cannot function according to constitutional provisions, he may declare President’s Rule in that state.

Such a **proclamation remains valid for an initial period of **❖six months.

Extension Rules:

It can be extended every 6 months, but only up to a maximum of 3 years, with Parliament's approval every time.

To extend beyond 1 year, certain conditions must be met:

National Emergency must be in operation, or

Election Commission certifies that elections cannot be held in that state.

question:
Among the following, which is not a qualification for membership in the Vidhan Sabha.

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: Not hold any office of profit
option_2: Have attained the age of 25 Years
solution:
The qualifications for membership in the Vidhan Sabha (State Legislative Assembly) are laid down in the Constitution of India (Article 173).

Required qualifications:

  1. Must be a citizen of India
  2. Must be at least 25 years of age
  3. Must not hold any office of profit under the government (with exceptions)
  4. Must possess other qualifications as prescribed by Parliament

"Knowledge of politics" is NOT a constitutional or legal requirement for contesting Vidhan Sabha elections.

question:
The minimum strength of the Council of Ministers in a state as per the Indian Constitution is ________ .

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
As per Article 164(1A) of the Indian Constitution, the minimum strength of the Council of Ministers in a state is 12 persons.

This includes the Chief Minister.

This provision was added by the 91st Constitutional Amendment Act, 2003 to prevent jumbo cabinets and ensure efficiency in governance.

Important Points:

The maximum size of the Council of Ministers cannot exceed 15% of the total strength of the State Legislative Assembly.

But there must be at least 12 ministers, regardless of the size of the assembly.

question:
Who has the power to prorogue the House or either House of State Legislature from time to time?

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
As per the Indian Constitution, the Governor of a state has the power to prorogue the House or either House of the State Legislature.

This power is given under Article 174(2)(a).

To prorogue means to end a session of the legislature without dissolving it.

The Governor exercises this power on the advice of the Chief Minister and the Council of Ministers.

Key Terms:

Summon – To call the house to meet

Prorogue – To end a session

Dissolve – To end the entire tenure of the House (only applicable to Legislative Assembly)

question:
Who is considered as the ‘linchpin of the Government’?

Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
option_3: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
solution:
The Prime Minister of India is often referred to as the "linchpin of the Government".

This is because the Prime Minister is the central coordinating figure in the functioning of the Union Government.

He is the head of the Council of Ministers, leads the executive, and is the chief advisor to the President.

All key decisions of the government are taken under his leadership.

Key Roles of the Prime Minister:

Leader of the Lok Sabha

Head of the Council of Ministers

Link between the President and the Cabinet

Represents the country nationally and internationally

question:
Which option is NOT correct in case of appointment of a Governor?

Higher Secondary 20/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
option_2: Cannot hold any office of profit during his tenure
option_3: Appointed for six years
option_4: Should be at least 35 years
solution:
The Governor of a state is appointed by the President of India as per Article 155 of the Constitution.

The correct tenure of a Governor is 5 years, not 6 years. Hence, option (c) is incorrect.

Constitutional Provisions (Article 157 & 158):

  1. Must be a citizen of India
  2. Must be at least 35 years old
  3. Shall not hold any office of profit during his term
  4. Appointed for a term of 5 years, but holds office at the pleasure of the President(So, 6 years is incorrect)

question:
On whose advice does the Governor appoint the ministers?

Higher Secondary 20/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
As per Article 164(1) of the Indian Constitution, the Governor appoints the other Ministers in the state on the advice of the Chief Minister.

The Chief Minister is the head of the Council of Ministers and plays the central role in recommending names for ministerial appointments.

The Governor must follow the advice of the Chief Minister in this regard.

Key Point:

The Chief Minister is appointed first, and then he/she advises the Governor to appoint other ministers.

question:
Who unfurls the flag at Rajpath on the Republic Day?

Higher Secondary 21/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
option_1: The Chief of Defence Staff
option_2: The President of India
option_3: The Chief Minister of Delhi
option_4: The Prime Minister of India
solution:
On Republic Day (26th January), the President of Indiaunfurls the national flag at Rajpath (now called Kartavya Path) in New Delhi.

The President is the constitutional head of the country and the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces.

This event marks the celebration of the adoption of the Constitution in 1950, and the President presides over the grand ceremonial parade.

Key Points:

Independence Day (15th August): Prime Minister hoists the flag at Red Fort.

Republic Day (26th January): President unfurls the flag at Kartavya Path.

question:
The Governor’s emoluments are decided by the:

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
The emoluments (salary and allowances) of the Governor are decided by the Parliament of India.

This is provided under Article 158(3) of the Indian Constitution.

Although the Governor functions at the state level, his salary and conditions of service are determined by the central government (Parliament), not the state legislature.

Key Point:

The salary is charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State, but the amount is fixed by Parliament.

question:
The ministers in the state hold office during the pleasure of the:

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
option_2: Speaker of the Legislative Assembly
solution:
As per Article 164(1) of the Indian Constitution, the ministers in a state (including the Chief Minister) hold office during the pleasure of the Governor.

However, this is a formal provision — in practice, the Governor acts on the advice of the Chief Minister.

If the Chief Minister loses majority in the Legislative Assembly, the Governor can dismiss the ministers.

Key Point:

Though the phrase is “pleasure of the Governor,” the real power lies with the Chief Minister as long as they enjoy the majority in the assembly.

question:
In which year did Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan assume office as the first Vice-President of India?

Graduate Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan assumed office as the first Vice-President of India in the year 1952.

He held the office from 1952 to 1962, serving two consecutive terms.

Later, he also became the second President of India in 1962, succeeding Dr. Rajendra Prasad.

Key Facts:

The office of Vice-President was created under Article 63 of the Constitution.

The first election to the post of Vice-President was held in 1952.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that ‘The President shall, notwithstanding the expiration of his/her term, continue to hold office until his successor enters upon his/her office’?

Graduate Level 25/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
Article 56(1)(c) of the Indian Constitution states:

“The President shall, notwithstanding the expiration of his term, continue to hold office until his successor enters upon his office.”

This provision ensures continuity in the office of the President and prevents a vacuum in the highest constitutional post.

Even after completing the 5-year term, the President remains in office until the next elected President takes charge.

Related Articles:

Article 54 – Election of the President

Article 58 – Qualifications for election as President

Article 61 – Impeachment of the President

Article 50 – Separation of judiciary from the executive (not related)

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that an election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of the President shall be completed before the expiration of the term?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
Article 62(1) of the Indian Constitution states that:

“An election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of the President shall be completed before the expiration of the term.”

This ensures a smooth transition of power and avoids any vacancy in the office of the President.

It also mentions that in case of a vacancy due to death, resignation, or removal, the election must be held within six months.

Related Articles:

Article 60 – Oath or affirmation by the President

Article 61 – Procedure for impeachment of the President

Article 59 – Conditions of the President’s office

question:
Who was the second vice President of India?

SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023
solution:
The second Vice President of India was Dr. Zakir Hussain.

He served as Vice President from 1962 to 1967.

After serving as Vice President, he was later elected as the third President of India in 1967, and was also the first Muslim President of the country.

Vice Presidents of India (Initial Order):

  1. Dr. S. Radhakrishnan – 1952 to 1962 (1st Vice President)
  2. Dr. Zakir Hussain – 1962 to 1967 (2nd Vice President)
  3. V. V. Giri – 1967 to 1969 (3rd Vice President)

question:
Who will cause every year, annual financial statements to be laid before the Legislative Assembly of the State?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
As per Article 202 of the Indian Constitution, the Governor of a state shall cause to be laid before the Legislative Assembly the Annual Financial Statement (also known as the State Budget) every year.

This statement contains the estimated receipts and expenditures of the state for the upcoming financial year.

Though the Finance Minister or Chief Minister presents the budget, it is done on behalf of the Governor.

Key Point:

This is similar to Article 112 at the central level, where the President lays the Union Budget before Parliament.

question:
When the President of India keeps a bill (except money bill and constitutional amendment bill) pending for an indefinite period, it is called______.

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)
option_1: absolute veto of the President
option_2: amendatory veto of the President
option_3: pocket veto of the President
option_4: suspensive veto of the President
solution:
When the President of India keeps a bill (except a money bill or constitutional amendment bill)pending indefinitely without giving assent, withholding it, or returning it, it is called a Pocket Veto.

This concept is not explicitly mentioned in the Constitution but is used in practice.

Unlike the US President, the Indian President has no time limit within which they must act on a bill.

The most famous use of Pocket Veto in India was by President Zail Singh in 1986, when he withheld the Post Office (Amendment) Bill.

Key Terms:

Absolute Veto – President rejects the bill outright.

Suspensive Veto – President returns the bill for reconsideration.

Amendatory Veto – President suggests amendments to the bill.

Pocket Veto – President takes no action, and the bill remains pending indefinitely.

question:
The President of India decides on the question as to the disqualification of Members of Parliament in consultation with the ____________.

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)
option_2: Supreme Court of India
option_4: Election Commission of India
solution:
As per Article 103 of the Indian Constitution, the President of India decides questions regarding disqualification of Members of Parliament.

However, the President is required to consult the Election Commission of India, and must act according to its opinion.

This ensures the decision is non-partisan and legally sound.

Important Points:

The disqualification may arise under:

Article 102 – Grounds for disqualification

Representation of the People Act, 1951

The President cannot act independently; the opinion of the Election Commission is binding.

question:
Who was the Prime Minister of India when the Fundamental Duties were first incorporated in the Constitution of India?

SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
The Fundamental Duties were first incorporated into the Indian Constitution through the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.

At that time, Indira Gandhi was the Prime Minister of India.

These duties were added as Part IV-A of the Constitution under Article 51A.

Initially, 10 Fundamental Duties were added, inspired by the Constitution of the USSR (now Russia).

Key Points:

42nd Amendment is also called the "Mini Constitution" due to its wide-ranging changes.

One more Fundamental Duty was added later by the 86th Amendment (2002), making the total 11.

question:
Who holds the authority of transferring judges from one High court to another High Court?

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (2nd shift)
option_1: The senior most judge of Supreme Court
option_2: The chief justice of Indie
option_3: The president of India
option_4: The law minister of India
solution:
The President of India holds the authority to transfer judges from one High Court to another, as per Article 222 of the Indian Constitution.

However, this transfer is done after consultation with the Chief Justice of India (CJI).

The recommendation of the CJI is binding, and the President acts on that advice.

Key Facts:

Article 222(1) – Deals with the transfer of High Court judges.

The CJI plays a key role, but the President is the appointing/transferring authority.

The transferred judge is entitled to a compensatory allowance.

question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding removal of the President of India?

A. The impeachment process can be initiated in either House of Parliament.

B. The impeachment charges must be signed by the one-third members of the House in which the process is initiated.

C. In the impeachment process, a 30 days' notice should be given to the President.

D. The impeachment resolution is passed by a majority of two-thirds of the total membership of that House.

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (2nd shift)
option_1: B and C only
option_2: A, B and C only
option_3: A, B, C and D
option_4: A and D only
solution:
The removal of the President of India is done through an impeachment process under Article 61 of the Constitution.

Let’s evaluate each statement:

A.The impeachment process can be initiated in either House of Parliament.

Correct – It can begin in either the Lok Sabha or the Rajya Sabha.

B.The impeachment charges must be signed by one-third members of the House.

Incorrect – The charges must be signed by at least one-fourth of the total number of members of that House.

C.30 days' notice should be given to the President.

Incorrect – A minimum 14-day notice must be given to the President.

D.The impeachment resolution is passed by a majority of two-thirds of the total membership of that House.

Correct – The resolution must be passed by a two-thirds majority of the total membership, not just those present and voting.

Correct Answer: (d) A and D only

question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the State Executive?

A. Article 152 of the Indian Constitution states 'Unless the context otherwise requires, the expression 'State' does not include Jammu and Kashmir'.

B. The 7th Constitutional Amendment Act has provided for the appointment of the same person as Governor for two or more states.

C. The Supreme Court clearly mentioned that the office of the Governor is under the control of the Central Government.

SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: B and C only
option_2: A and C only
option_3: A, B and C
option_4: A and B only
solution:
A.Article 152 excludes Jammu and Kashmir from the definition of 'State' (prior to the abrogation of Article 370).

B.The 7th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956 allows the same person to be Governor of two or more states.

C.The Supreme Court has not declared that the Governor is under Central Government control. The office of Governor is constitutionally independent.

Correct Answer: (d) A and B only

question:
The Governor of an Indian state before entering upon his office takes an oath or affirmation before ____________.

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: the Chief Justice of the High Court exercising jurisdiction in relation to the State
option_2: the President of India
option_3: the Chief Minister of the concerned state
option_4: the Prime Minister of India
solution:
Before entering office, the Governor of an Indian state takes the oath or affirmation in the presence of the

Chief Justice of the High Court of the concerned state.

If the Chief Justice is unavailable, the oath is administered by the senior-most judge of that High Court.

This is provided under Article 159 of the Indian Constitution.

Oath includes:

Faithfulness to the Constitution

Preservation of the sovereignty and integrity of India

Diligent discharge of duties

question:
What is the duty of the Chief Minister, as mentioned under Article 167 of the Indian Constitution?

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: Communication of all decisions of the Council of Ministers to the Governor.
option_2: Appointment and removal of Council of the Ministers.
option_3: Appointment of the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly.
option_4: Appointment of Advocate General of the state in consultation with Attorney general.
solution:
Article 167 of the Indian Constitution outlines the duties of the Chief Minister to the Governor.

The key duty under this Article is the:

“Communication of all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to the administration of the affairs of the State and proposals for legislation to the Governor.”

This ensures that the Governor is kept informed of state matters and decisions taken by the Council of Ministers.

question:
Who among the following served the shortest tenure as the Prime Minister of India?

SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
Chandra Shekhar served the shortest tenure as the Prime Minister of India.

His term lasted from 10 November 1990 to 21 June 1991, which is approximately 223 days.

He led a minority government with outside support from the Congress Party, which later withdrew support.

Comparison with others:

HD Deva Gowda – ~11 months

VP Singh – ~11 months

IK Gujral – ~11 months

Chandra Shekhar – ~7.5 months (shortest among them)

question:
The Inter-State Council consists of ______ ministers of Cabinet rank in the Union Council of Ministers nominated by the Prime Minister of India.

SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
The Inter-State Council is a constitutional body set up under Article 263 of the Indian Constitution to promote cooperation and coordination between states and the Union.

The Council is headed by the Prime Minister and includes:

Six Union Cabinet Ministers nominated by the Prime Minister

Chief Ministers of all states

Chief Ministers of Union Territories with Legislative Assemblies

Administrators of UTs without legislatures

And other ministers as invited

question:
Who appoints the Chief Justice of India?

SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
The Chief Justice of India (CJI) is appointed by the President of India, as per Article 124(2) of the Constitution.

By convention, the senior-most judge of the Supreme Court is appointed as the CJI.

The appointment is done in consultation with the outgoing Chief Justice and on the advice of the Council of Ministers.

question:
What is the minimum age (in years) a person should be if he/she is willing to be appointed as the Governor of a state in India?

SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
According to Article 157 of the Indian Constitution, a person must:

  1. Be a citizen of India
  2. Have completed 35 years of age
  3. Not hold any office of profit under the Government of India, any state, or any local authority.

The Governor is appointed by the President of India under Article 155.

The Governor acts as the constitutional head of the state, similar to how the President is the head of the Union.

Term of office: 5 years (as per Article 156), but the Governor holds office at the pleasure of the President.

A person can be appointed as the Governor of two or more states simultaneously (as per 7th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956).

question:
Who administers the Union Territories of India?

SSC MTS 19/06/2023 (Morning)
option_4: Member of Legislative Assembly
solution:
As per Article 239 of the Indian Constitution, the President of India administers the Union Territories (UTs) through an Administrator or Lieutenant Governor appointed by him.

UTs like Delhi, Puducherry, and Jammu & Kashmir have legislative assemblies, but their administration is still under the control of the President through the Lieutenant Governor.

Other UTs (like Lakshadweep, Andaman & Nicobar Islands, etc.) are governed directly by Administrators.

question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the benefits of the retired President of India?

A. The former President of India will also be entitled to a monthly pension of ₹2.5 lakh.

B. He/She is entitled to a secretarial staff comprising a private secretary, a personal assistant, an additional private secretary, two peons, and office expenses up to ₹1 lakh per annum.

C. He/She is also entitled to free highest-class travel anywhere in India, accompanied by one person, by rail, air, or steamer.

SSC CGL Tier II (02/03/2023)
option_1: A and B only
option_3: A and C only
option_4: A, B and C
solution:
A retired President of India is entitled to a monthly pension of ₹2.5 lakh.

He/She is provided with secretarial staff, which includes:

One Private Secretary

One Additional Private Secretary

One Personal Assistant

Two Peons

Office expenses up to ₹1 lakh per annum

The former President is entitled to free highest-class travel anywhere in India by rail, air, or steamer, along with one companion.

Additional Information:

These benefits are governed by the President’s Emoluments and Pension Act, 1951.

Other facilities provided to a retired President include:

Furnished rent-free accommodation

Telephone facilities

One car with a driver

Lifetime medical facilities

SPG or equivalent security protection is also provided as per protocol.

question:
Who among the following Presidents of India was also the deputy chairman of the Planning Commission?

SSC CGL 01/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
Pranab Mukherjee, before becoming the 13th President of India, held several key positions in the Indian government.

He served as the Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission of India from 1991 to 1996.

In addition to that, he also held important portfolios such as:

Finance Minister

External Affairs Minister

Defence Minister

He was known for his deep understanding of policy and governance.

question:
Which of the following statements about the Vice President of India is INCORRECT?

SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Members of State legislatures do not take part in his elections.
option_2: He acts as the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha.
option_3: The Vice President is elected for five years.
option_4: He can be removed from his office by the President approved through a resolution passed by the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha.
solution:
The Vice President of India is elected for a term of 5 years –Correct.

He is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha –Correct.

Members of State Legislatures do not participate in the election of the Vice President –Correct.

The incorrect statement is that the Vice President can be removed by the President through a resolution passed by both Houses.

In reality, the Vice President can only be removed by a resolution passed by the Rajya Sabha by a majority vote, and agreed to by the Lok Sabha.

The President has no role in the removal of the Vice President.

question:
The emoluments and allowances of the President and other expenditure relating to his office is charged on the ______ of India.

SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
The emoluments (salary) and allowances of the President of India are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.

This means the amount is not subject to vote in Parliament — it is automatically granted.

The Consolidated Fund of India is the chief account of the Government of India and includes:

All revenues received by the government (tax and non-tax)

All loans raised by the government

This provision ensures the independence and dignity of the office of the President.

question:
Which is NOT correct about the powers of the Chief Minister?

Graduate Level 04/08/2022 (Shift- 2)
option_1: He allocates portfolios among ministers.
option_2: He presides over the meetings of the Council of Ministers.
option_3: When he resigns or dies, it has no effect in the functioning of the council of ministers.
option_4: The Governor appoints ministers on His recommendations.
solution:
The Chief Minister is the head of the Council of Ministers in a state.

He allocates portfolios among the ministers –Correct.

He presides over the meetings of the Council of Ministers –Correct.

The Governor appoints ministers based on the recommendation of the Chief Minister –Correct.

The incorrect statement is that the resignation or death of the Chief Minister has no effect.

In reality, if the Chief Minister resigns or dies, the entire Council of Ministers is dissolved, because they hold office during his pleasure and leadership.

question:
Who among the following is NOT appointed by the President of India?

Graduate Level 05/08/2022 (Shift- 3)
option_1: Ambassadors and High Commissioners
option_2: Comptroller and Auditor General of India
option_3: Attorney General of India
option_4: Solicitor General of India
solution:
The following are appointed by the President of India:

Ambassadors and High Commissioners –Yes, appointed by the President.

Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India –Yes, under Article 148.

Attorney General of India –Yes, under Article 76.

The Solicitor General of India is NOT appointed by the President.

He is appointed by the Appointments Committee of the Cabinet (ACC), headed by the Prime Minister.

The Solicitor General assists the Attorney General but is not a constitutional post.

question:
Who among the following was the third Vice- President of India?

SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Morning)
solution:
V. V. Giri was the third Vice President of India.

He served as Vice President from 1967 to 1969.

He later became the fourth President of India (1969–1974).

He is the only person to be elected President as an independent candidate.

Before becoming Vice President, he held several significant posts:

Governor of Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, and Karnataka

High Commissioner to Ceylon (Sri Lanka)

Union Labour Minister

Additional Information:

V. V. Giri played a key role in shaping India’s labour policies.

He was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1975, India's highest civilian award.

He resigned as Vice President to contest the Presidential election in 1969.

He was born in Berhampur, Odisha in 1894 and was also a freedom fighter.

question:
The election of the next Vice- President is to be held within _____ of the expiry of the term of office of the outgoing Vice- President.

SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
As per the Vice-President (Election) Rules and conventions guided by the Constitution of India, the election for the next Vice-President must be held within 60 days before the expiry of the term of the outgoing Vice-President.

This ensures that there is no vacancy in the office and the transition is smooth.

The Vice-President of India holds office for a term of 5 years (Article 67).

The election process is conducted by the Election Commission of India.

Additional Information:

The Vice-President is elected by an Electoral College consisting of members of both Houses of Parliament (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha).

Members of State Legislative Assemblies do not participate in this election.

In case of a vacancy due to death, resignation, or removal, a new election must be held as soon as possible, but no later than 6 months.
